Discrete choice analysis is a statistical technique. In these models the dependent variable is a binary variable. Instances of discrete choice analysis are probit, logit and multinomial models. They are applied in econometrics, marketing research and transportation mode and route choice.
Specific model types123
Probit
Logit
Multinomial logit (MNL) - enhanced logit to allow for more than two alternatives in a choice
Multinomial probit model
MNL is not suitable for problems with correlated alternatives due to the IIA property (irrelevance of independent alternatives). (See the blue bus/red bus example 1 or path choice example2 A number of alternatives have been proposed to overcome this problem:
Nested logit - captures correlations between alternatives by partitioning the choice set into 'nests'
Cross-nested logit 4 (CNL) - alternatives may belong to more than one nest
Generalised extreme value model5 - the general class of model, derived from the random utility model2 to which multinomial logit and nested logit belong
Mother logit
Hierarchical logit
C-logit 6 - captures correlations between alternatives using with a 'commonality factor'
Path size logit 2
Paired combinatorial logit 7
Hybrid or mixed logit model - multinomial probit model with logit kernel2,89. Can be applied to route choice 10
Latent class choice models
